questions.question_text: Which code will successfully create a BODILESS PACKAGE to standardize CONSTANTS and EXCEPTIONS declarations?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C because constant value is initialized. Not B where constant is not initialized.

The syntax is: 
PRAGMA EXCEPTION_INIT (exception_name, error_code)

choices.G: A PL/SQL procedure can invoke an external code block written in a different programming language.
choices.F: Host variables can be referenced inside any PL/SQL subprogram.
choices.D: Reuse of parsed PL/SQL code from the shared SQL area reduces parsing overhead.
choices.E: A subprogram's session state is retained even if any of the sessionâ€™s instantiated subprograms are invalidated and revalidated.
choices.C: Subprograms are cached by default and shared among users, thereby reducing memory requirements.
choices.A: Results of a subprogram can be cached in the SGA such that sessions connected to the same instance can reuse these results when available.
choices.B: Users granted execute privilege on a procedure compiled with definer's rights require grants to access objects belonging to the definer that are referenced in the procedure.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CDG
A is only true for functions, C is stated in Oracle documentation, D and G are true

comments.content: so i say A, C, G
Reference for A is talking about PL/SQL Function Result Cache and question is talking about subprograms (functions and procedures). So I stay for C,D,G.

discussion.content:
Reference for A:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/lnpls/plsql-subprograms.html#GUID-250BDBBB-0CD6-4D56-9DDF-6FCEDC110D00


Reference for C:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/lnpls/plsql-subprograms.html#GUID-E03F512B-1A30-43B4-8DCA-64DA68AE7CE4

questions.question_text: Which three are true about PL/SQL subprograms? (Choose three.)
Which three PL/SQL-only data types can be used in queries and native dynamic SQL issued from PL/SQL in the server? (Choose three.)

choices.E: a predefined PL/SQL-only data type like BOOLEAN
choices.B: a record declared in a procedure
choices.C: an associative array indexed by PLS_INTEGER
choices.F: an associative array indexed by VARCHAR2
choices.A: a record declared in an anonymous block
choices.D: a record declared in a package specification

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CDF
Don't get fooled by google Copilot if it says E is the right choice. CD & F.

A E G 
this is the correct answer
User-defined functions can appear in a SQL statement anywhere SQL functions can appear

questions.question_text: Which three are true about user-defined functions? (Choose three.)

choices.E: They can appear in the select list of a SELECT statement.
choices.D: They need not return any values.
choices.G: They can be used in CONNECT BY and START WITH clauses.
choices.C: They must be defined with at least one parameter.
choices.A: They can be used in ORDER BY and GROUP BY clauses.
choices.B: They can be executed as standalone commands.
choices.F: Functions can call only other functions.

choices.B: It results in an error because Authid Definer is missing from MYPROC.
choices.C: It results in an error because USERB doesn't have select privilege on USERA.EMP.
choices.A: It results in an error because Authid Current_User is missing from MYPROC.

questions.question_text:
Examine these facts:
Table EMP exists in schema USERA with columns SALARY and EMP_ID.
EMP_ID is the primary key with values ranging from 1 to 100.
USERA now executes these statements successfully:
//IMG//

USERA then grants execute privilege on procedure MYPROC to USERB.
USERB exists in the database identified by pdb1 but does not have select privilege on USERA.EMP.
USERB now executes these statements:
conn userB/userB@pdb1
execute userA.myproc;
Which is true?

discussion.content: D - If the AUTHID clause is not specified, Oracle will default to using the AUTHID DEFINER
D tested out. Because you're executing as definer's rights so even if its selecting from a table where UserB doesnt have any rights on, its executing as if he's userA who does have rights.
